export.title: Enable pipelines config sharing
export.description: Allows other Bitbucket repositories to import pipeline configurations from this file. A shared pipeline definition can't contain another `import` property.

pipelines.title: Build pipelines
pipelines.description:
The start of your pipelines definitions. Under this keyword you must define your build pipelines using at least one of the following:

  * default (for all branches that don't match any of the following)
  * branches (Git and Mercurial)
  * tags (Git)
  * bookmarks (Mercurial)

branches.title: Branch-specific build pipelines
branches.description:
Defines a section for all branch-specific build pipelines. The names or expressions in this section are matched against:

  * branches in your Git repository
  * named branches in your Mercurial repository

You can use glob patterns for handling the branch names.

bookmarks.title: Bookmark-specific build pipelines (to be used in Mercurial repositories)
bookmarks.description:
Defines all bookmark-specific build pipelines. 

The names or expressions in this section are matched against bookmarks in your Mercurial repository. 

You can use glob patterns for handling the tag names.

custom.title: Manually triggered build pipelines
custom.description: Defines pipelines that can only be triggered manually or scheduled from the Bitbucket Cloud interface.

tags.title: Tag-specific build pipelines
tags.description:
Defines all tag-specific build pipelines. 

The names or expressions in this section are matched against tags and annotated tags in your Git repository. 

You can use glob patterns for handling the tag names.

pull-requests.title: Pull-request-specific build pipelines
pull-requests.description:
A special pipeline which only runs on pull requests. Pull-requests has the same level of indentation as branches.

This type of pipeline runs a little differently to other pipelines. When it's triggered, we'll merge the destination branch into your working branch before it runs. If the merge fails we will stop the pipeline.

default.title: Default build pipeline for branches
default.description:
The default pipeline runs on every push to the repository, unless a branch-specific pipeline is defined. 
You can define a branch pipeline in the branches section.

Note: The default pipeline doesn't run on tags or bookmarks.

import.title: Location to import pipelines config from
import.description: The import needs to match the following format: {repo-slug|repo-uuid}:{tag|branch-name}:{pipeline-name}

variables.description: List of variables for the custom pipeline

name.description: Name of a variable for the custom pipeline

step.title: Build execution unit
step.description:
Define s a build execution unit. 

Steps are executed in the order that they appear in the bitbucket-pipelines.yml file. 
You can use up to 10 steps in a pipeline.

name.title: Name of the step
name.description: You can add a name to a step to make displays and reports easier to read and understand.

script.description: Commands to execute in the step

after-script.title: Commands to execute after the step succeeds or fails
after-script.description:
Commands inside an after-script section will run when the step succeeds or fails. This could be useful for clean up commands, test coverage, notifications, or rollbacks you might want to run, especially if your after-script uses the value of BITBUCKET_EXIT_CODE.

Note: If any commands in the after-script section fail:

* we won't run any more commands in that section

* it will not effect the reported status of the step.

items.description: Glob pattern for the path to the artifacts

oneOf.title: Files produced by a step to share with a following step
oneOf.description: Defines files to be shared from one step to a later step in your pipeline. Artifacts can be defined using glob patterns.

download.description: Indicates whether to download artifact in the step

items.description: Glob pattern for the path to the artifacts

trigger.title: Step trigger type
trigger.description: Specifies whether a step will run automatically or only after someone manually triggers it. You can define the trigger type as manual or automatic. If the trigger type is not defined, the step defaults to running automatically. The first step cannot be manual. If you want to have a whole pipeline only run from a manual trigger then use a custom pipeline.

deployment.title: Type of environment for the deployment step
deployment.description: Sets the type of environment for your deployment step, used in the Deployments dashboard.

oidc.title: OpenID Connect
oidc.description: Enables the use of OpenID Connect with Pipelines and your resource server. The oidc value must be set to true to set up and configure OpenID Connect.

condition.title: Execute step when only condition is satisfied
condition.description: Allows for steps to execute when certain conditions or rules are satisfied

includePaths.title: List of paths for changeset condition.

parallel.title: Set of steps to run concurrently
parallel.description:
Parallel steps enable you to build and test faster, by running a set of steps at the same time.

The total number of build minutes used by a pipeline will not change if you make the steps parallel, but you'll be able to see the results sooner.

There is a limit of 10 for the total number of steps you can run in a pipeline, regardless of whether they are running in parallel or serial.

script.description:
Contains a list of commands that are executed in sequence. 

Scripts are executed in the order in which they appear in a step. 

We recommend that you move large scripts to a separate script file and call it from the bitbucket-pipelines.yml.

pipe.title: Pipe to execute
pipe.description:
Pipes make complex tasks easier, by doing a lot of the work behind the scenes.
This means you can just select which pipe you want to use, and supply the necessary variables.
You can look at the repository for the pipe to see what commands it is running.

Learn more about pipes: https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/pipes-958765631.html

pipe.title: Pipe identifier
pipe.description:
Pipes make complex tasks easier, by doing a lot of the work behind the scenes.
This means you can just select which pipe you want to use, and supply the necessary variables.
You can look at the repository for the pipe to see what commands it is running.

Learn more about pipes: https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/pipes-958765631.html

variables.description: Environment variables passed to the pipe

definitions.title: Defines resources used elsewhere in the pipeline configuration
definitions.description:
Define resources used elsewhere in your pipeline configuration. 
Resources can include:

* services that run in separate Docker containers – see https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/gC8kN

* caches – see https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/bA1hNQ#Cachingdependencies-custom-caches

* YAML anchors - a way to define a chunk of your yaml for easy re-use - see https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/yaml-anchors-960154027.html

pipelinesUnderDefinitions.title: Pipeline definitions that are defined to be used elsewhere
pipelinesUnderDefinitions.description: Defines pipelines that can be used under root level pipelines section.

services.title: Defines services that run in separate Docker containers
services.description: Rather than trying to build all the resources you might need into one large image, we can spin up separate docker containers for services. This will tend to speed up the build, and makes it very easy to change a single service without having to redo your whole image.

variables.description: Environment variables passed to the service container

memory.description: Memory limit for the service container, in megabytes

cache-key-files.title: Cache key
cache-key-files.description: Checksum of these file paths will be used to generate the cache key

items.description: Glob pattern for the cache key files

caches.title: Defines custom caches to be used by pipelines.
caches.description:
Caching build dependencies and directories enables faster builds and reduces the number of consumed build minutes.

Learn more about caches: https://support.atlassian.com/bitbucket-cloud/docs/cache-dependencies

oneOf.title: Path to the directory to be cached
oneOf.description: Path to the directory to be cached, can be absolute or relative to the clone directory

key.title: Cache key
key.description: Checksum of these file paths will be used to generate the cache key

path.title: Cache path
path.description: Path to the directory to be cached, can be absolute or relative to the clone directory

options.title: Global settings that apply to all pipelines
options.description: Contains global settings that apply to all your pipelines. The main keyword you'd use here is max-time.

docker.description: A flag to add Docker to all build steps in all pipelines

max-time.description: Maximum amount of minutes a step can execute

size.title: Multiplier of the resources allocated to a pipeline step
size.description:
You can allocate additional resources to a step, or to the whole pipeline. 
By specifying the size of 2x, you'll have double the resources available (eg. 4GB memory → 8GB memory).

At this time, valid sizes are 1x and 2x.

clone.title: Contains settings to clone the repository into a container
clone.description:
Contains settings for when we clone your repository into a container. Settings here include:

* lfs - Support for Git lfs

* depth - the depth of the Git clone.

depth.description: Depth of Git clones for all pipelines (supported only for Git repositories)

lfs.description: Enables the download of LFS files in the clone (supported only for Git repositories)

runAsUser.title: The UID of a user in the docker image to run as
runAsUser.description: Overrides image's default user, specified user UID must be an existing user in the image with a valid home directory

simpleImage.title: Name of the Docker image which may or may not include registry URL, tag, and digest value
simpleImage.description:
The Docker container to run your builds.

see: https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/kYU5Lw for details

privateImage.description: A docker image hosted in a private repository

username.description: Username to use to fetch the Docker image

password.description: Password to use to fetch the Docker image

email.description: Email to use to fetch the Docker image

awsImage.description: A docker image hosted by AWS ECR

oidc-role.description: AWS IAM Role assumable using OpenID Connect
